title: The Role of Orbitofrontal Cortex in Cognitive Planning in the Rat

author: Kevin Miller, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University

segmentation: Alright, my name is Kevin Miller, my graduate student at Princeton with Carlos Brody and Matt, both Nick and I'm really excited to hear this morning tell you about some work that we've done studying cognitive planning in the rat before I do that, I want to take a second to say what we mean when we talk about cognitive planning, but we.
Mean is just model based decision making mean decision making that's guided by an internal model of the outcomes of your actions.
You have some idea what's going to happen in the world when you make an action.
You use that idea to inform your action.
That's model based decision making.
That's what I mean by planning.
It's a really simple idea.
Turns out to be kind of hard to study because the very same behavior can either be planned or unplanned depending on the representations that guided.
So as an example of that, you may be making your way through the world and encounter a stimulus.
It looks like that and you may emit the appropriate response.
If what was going on in your mind when you did that was some representation like this.
I know that if I press the pedal the car is going to slow down.
That's what I want.
Here's why I want that.
Then you can be such a plan that decision, another thing you might have done is just memorized the right answer.
Just say I know that when I see a red light, I press the pedal, that's it.
And the very same behavior can have been model free just by watching you do that, we can't really know which of those strategies is going on.
So we want to study this.
We need special behaviors that let us pull these things apart.
The kind of.
Classic traditional way to do this is with these one time through tasks and show an example of one of those which is outcome devaluation.
The ideas in this cartoon version you have an animal and you train him that pressing this level leads to one outcome and pressing this leads to another outcome.
Then separately you feed him these outcomes until he's no longer interested in little Nuggets and then give him a choice between the lovers.
The idea is that if he is learned that this lever goes to that in this letter goes to that he knows he doesn't want this, he's going to press this lever when given that choice test.
This is a classic way of studying planning.
One sort of problem with it and with other things that are out there that there one time through is this flavor.
You can kind of do this once and you get one behavioral measure at the end.
Of course, if we want to study mechanism, we want to look at neural correlates if we want to control its need to aggregate data over many instances of behavior.
So if we want to do that, we're going to need some new some new tasks, and so that's what I'm going to tell you about today.

Specifically, I'm going to tell you about a planning task that we've built for rats a couple of ways of quantifying behavior on that task, and then we're going to do some causal interventions were going to turn off brain regions and watch how it pushes behavior around, and finally some preliminary data from what we wanted all along, which is neural correlates of planning in the orbital frontal cortex, specifically here.
So this is the planning task for rats.
This is a variant of the famous or maybe infamous Nathaniel Dot 2011.
Two step task which is exploding over human cognitive neuroscience and we're trying to bring it to rodent neuroscience.

These two reward probabilities are different from each other, and they're changing all the time, so this is a continuous learning environment, and the thing that your animal has to do is he's gotta learn the reward probabilities and then he's got to make the choice at the top level.
That's going to get him to the state with the highest reward probability.
The way that we've instantiated this for rats is in a behavior chamber that looks like this.

The way it.
It works is like this, the beginning, the top centered one lights up to say the trial is ready.

Pokes it to say I'm ready for the trial.

At that side port.
